Remember what I wrote in "Who's Swimming Naked" realinvestmentadvice.com/kas… They conveniently forgot how bullish they have been...

Reducing the capital gains tax is meaningless when no one has capital gains, and his tax package reduced the value of capital losses! The next problem facing the markets and the domestic economy- assuming a continuation of lower stock prices -- will be the negative wealth effect.
Check

Near the close of trading the S&P Index hit (2400) the low end of my "fair market value" range (of 2400-2500). From the September high, the S&P Index is now down by over 500 handles and 360 handles lower than when I wrote my 15 Surprises for 2019 in late November.

As I suggested in today's opener much of the decline lies at the foot of the policy and behavior of the President - rather than Fed policy/comments. The number of cabinet members and senior White House officials that have left in dismay (Mattis) or disrepute is unprecedented.

Increasingly Trump's isolated nature, embracing of strong arm world leaders (at the expense of our allies), inexperience and lack of coherent and coordinated policies are making market participants uneasy.

Stated simply, it looks like the US government has no idea what it is doing - it is unguided, led by Trump, and, seemingly, his daughter and son in law. This is a deeply serious situation in a flat and interconnected world.

Reducing the capital gains tax is meaningless when no one has capital gains - and his tax package reduced the value of capit losses The next problem facing the markets and the domestic economy - assuming a continuation of lower stock prices - will be the negative wealth effect
Merry Christmas. Mr. President.

Didnt you say in your meeting with Pelosi that you would take the responsibility?

From yesterday on @realmoney @jimcramer @carlquintanilla @tomkeene "Opportunities come infrequently. When it rains gold, put out the bucket, not the thimble." - Warren Buffett Being greedy when others are fearful (h/t The Oracle of Omaha) is easy to say but more

difficult to execute when stock prices are falling so swiftly. It's not exactly raining gold now (see quote above) and it might not be time to take out the bucket but it may be raining silver and it is time for me to take out the cup. Short term and long term investors should
be rejoicing and taking advantage of bargains - though the sledding in 2019 is bound to be difficult. Nevertheless, this approach has served me well over the years.

On @realmoney I have moved to large sized SPY (in my trading long rental) on this morning's weakness. (My cost basis today is about $256.35). This reflects my view that the market's reaction to the Fed (and other factors) was incorrect as the Fed is still very much data dependent

Moreover, the add on is a reflection that Mr. Market had moved to being slightly undervalued relative to "fair market value" and the upside reward v. downside risk is materially attractive over the next 30-60 days. My view is that I want to buy stocks into the current weakness.
Like going "all out" in July and shorting in the late Summer/early Fall this is a contrarian view. But I am fine with it. @jimcramer @tomkeene

On @realmoney There is No Crying in Investing and Trading * Zip it, Doris! "Are you crying? There's no crying. There's no crying in baseball." - Tom Hanks, A League of Our Own piped.video/watch?v=6M8szlSa… There are numerous lessons we should gather from the month of December's

market swoon. Most importantly we should learn "Who Is Swimming Naked?" realmoney.thestreet.com/doug… and avoid the a bad actors in the future. Above all we should have learned that the investment mosaic is complex - its ingredients consist of a wide swath of factors.

Also we should have learned that the business is tough and that the number one consideration should always be - what is the upside reward relative to the downside risk. Trade opportunistically and keep your emotions intact - because there is no crying in investing and trading!
